titleStmt.title: M112, set 1 of 3 [The Reader: manner brings in suggestions that give it another meaning]. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 4 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M112, set 1 of 3 [The Reader: manner brings in suggestions that give it another meaning]. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 4 fols.
p. 33 with fragment paginated p. 30 on verso.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
But again down on the the curtain rises.
The trumpets sound; the flag blows and the
shadowy insubstantial life txmxmxx of Squires, nobles
Maids of honour (hnour) and country gentlemen (gentlmen) is before us.
In one second we are in the thick of love; murder; adultery.
is before us. There is and his ;
there is the adulterer (adulterere); and the villain.
Supper is laid; the cards are on the table, and next moment
the husband throwing open the door sees his wife lying in
the arms of her lover. The yellow pages in Record offices
and Muniments rooms with (wit) their contortions (contorsions), their evasions,
give place to outright speech. In the play itself (tself) all is
evident, outspoken (outapoken). In real (r al) life all is shadowy and
suppressed.

But by degrees (degrrees) the dramatist sheds his anonymity.
He separates himself from his audience. He pauses, sometimes;
he diverts (di erts) the interest from the action to the motive (mtove)
motive behind the action. What, he broods in
, is the effect of mercy?--- if the adulters
are confronted not with death but with a guilty conscience?
As the plays come faster and faster, as the curtain rises
again and again, upon , , ,
, -- anonymity and the pressure of the
audience cease to bind the playwright. The reader loses his
anonymity too. He chooses (chhoses); he discriminates (discrimitaes). Here are
knicknacks (kick nacks); curiosities; illustrations of the time. But
here on the other hand, what we call for short ourselves--
the thought that we think instinctively (instcintively), the comment that

manner brings in suggestions that give it another meaning
almost. the word suggests often the manner of the clothes. We cannot shut out the contrast often between
the past and the present. And as the habit of reading becomes
universal many varieties (varities) of reader split off.
There are the specialised (specilaised) readers whose power of drawing out
the meaning of words is tremendously developed; so that
remain attached to certain aspects of the printed (rinted) page;
the scholars, the students (sudents). Again (Agaian) there is the very
large class (vlass) of perfectly literate people who run (whoruns)
who run their eyes over miles of print yet never read a word.
The reader at the moment is probably the [illeg.] reader.
When the reader proper, with his power to make (m kae)
houses (ouses) and countries visible, men and women and their thoughts (though)
and emotions from marks on a piece (ice) of (eof) paper bec
came into existence it is difficult to say. He is always
changing (chnaging). The is now developing (develpoing) his eye. The
is developing his ear. The fate of (if) literature of
course is in his hands. But Axxxhe He is still is still apparently reading

One reason why is still read is simply
the inadequacy of Shakespearean (Shakespriean) criticism (cri cism). The inadequacy of
that criticism is means that is due of course to the
it is always autobiographical criticism.
xxxxxxxxxxxxx It is a commonplace (comm nplace) to (tp) say that every
critic finds his own features in Shakespeare (Shakepare). His variety
is such that every one wxxxx can find scattered here or
there the [that which?] he can development (develop ent) of some one of his own attributes (attrbutes).
The critic then accents what is he is responsive to, and so
composes his own meaning, in Shakespeare's (Shakesperes) words.
The S. the S. the S.

that of the , the Cxmxmxxxx , the
the and above all the Cliffords (Cliffo ds) has become
like a precious stone not to be mixed (mized) with baser metal.
When Lord marries
it (ifit) was "held a very mean match
an indiscretion (indiscreet on) on part of him"
She believes (believss) in the immortality of the body as firmly as
in the immortality of the soul.

Yet there were moments when even this carapace of
possessions proved too heavy for her; when on the first day
xmxmxmxmmxmxx If I had not excellent book
here to comfort me, I were in a pitiable case, having so
many troubles as I have here, but when I read in that,
I scorn (nscorn) and make light of them all, and a little part of
his beauteous spirit infuses itself in me."

She adds that postscript (postcriot) wxmxmxmxmxmx to a letter about a
little cabinet and cup which she had left with Lady
when she borrowed a hundred pounds of her.

But it is only when she reads that she comments.
When she goes to the play she says only "Supped with
my Lord and Lady and after supper
I (OI) saw the play of the Mad Lover..." or
"We stood to see the Masque in the box with my Lady
" It was when the playhouses were shut
presumably that the reader was born. xmxmxmxmxmxmxm
The curious (cur us) faculty of making houses and countries
visible (visble), and men and women and their emotions,
from marks on a printed page was undeveloped (undevleoped) as

so long as the play was dominant (domenant). The audience at the
playhouse (plahouse) had to draw in the play with their eyes and ears.
Without a book of the words they could not deepen and revive
the impression left by the play, or ask those questions that
are debated daily now in every newspaper. The lack of general (generl)
reading (r ading) accounts (acconts) for the long pause between Shakespeare's (Sahkespsreas)
death and the 18th (i8th) century (centiry) when the plays of Shakespeare (Shakespre)
hung suspended unrealised (unreaslied). Even in 17 - could
say that Shakespeare (Shakespere) still lacked half his proper fame.
It accounts (accojts) too for the scarcity of criticism, and for the
general nature of what criticism (critisim) there was. Both and
are writing for the [small? still?] (s ll) critical public,
and thus deal general questions and not (andnot) with
particularities (partciularities) and personalities (personalitties). Mxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxe
mxmxmmxmxmxmxmmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmmxmx
primxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxy
xmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx

A life history of the reader during the past
four hundred years would be needed discover (disocver) at what point he lost
the acuteness (acuten ss) of his eyes; of his ears. at what point he
developed (devloped) the (he) power of association (asscoation); so that now a word printed
in the old spelling suggests a thousand (thosand) a

The biographer of the reader during the past four
hundred years would (w uld) discover at what point his ear lost
its acuteness; when his eyes (ey d) became dull; when to balance
this loss, he became conscious (cosncious) of suggestions and echoes,
and as time passed added much that was
unintended by the wxmxmxx writer. It would show that

we lost much when (whe) the p spectator was transformed (transfomed) into the reader (read)
the sound of the spoken (spoeken) word; a thousand suggestions that
the dramatist (dramtist) conveys by (b) gestures, by grouping and the
inflection of the voice. as if alone that proved by the
the effort we make in reading the early (earky) plays
to supply the trumpets and the flags, the citizens and
the apprentices (apprenetices). And in attempting this the (fthe) reader is
perpetually baffled; He is apt to become not a reader,
but a student (st dent); and as his reading power develops,
and as the habit of reading becomes universal,
there split off the specialised (specilaised) readers with their
tremendously developed power of drawing (ddrawing) out (o ) the meaning
of words; and again the very large class of perfectly
literate people who though they strip many miles of print (pint)
yearly from paper never (mever) read a word; and finally the reader,
who like Lady , read excellent book
when they are in trouble, "and a little part of his beauteous (beautoeus)
spirit infuses itself in me." And the reader is always
changing, The cinema (cimea) is now developing (develpping) his eyes; the Broadcast (Braod)
cast is developing (develpoing) his ear. He is still causing books to be
printed His imprtance can be gauged (gausged) by the act that
when his attention is distracted, in times of public crisis,
the writer exclaims: I cannot write any more. I have no
audience.
